input.content: You are on an island populated by two tribes. Members of one tribe consistently lie. Members of the other tribe always tell the truth. Tribe members can recognize one another, but you can't tell them apart. You meet two people, C and D on the island. C says, 'Exactly one of us is from the liars tribe.' Which tribe is D from?

prompt.ideal: D is from the Liars tribe.

sampled.completion:
"I don't think so," says an expert.
"It is a very unusual thing," says the head of the National Organization for Rare Disorders.
"It has not been a very common problem at all," says the head of the American Foundation for Clinical Research.
"I don't think it's a common problem," says a physician who is a medical consultant for a major insurance company.
A number of medical researchers say that the incidence of "mild cognitive impairment" in patients with cancer is higher than what has been previously thought.
The American Cancer Society estimates that about 1 out of 6 patients with cancer will experience "mild cognitive changes" during the course of the disease.
The National Cancer Institute says that the incidence of mild cognitive changes (mCNS) in cancer patients ranges from about 1-4% among adults.
The American Cancer Society says that about 2,000,000 cancer patients in the U.S. each year may experience a "major cognitive change."
The "mild cognitive impairment" - which can be caused by a variety of factors, including certain chemotherapy drugs - can range from a very mild "foggy thinking" to a more moderate "memory loss."
The National Cancer Institute says that mCNS "are more commonly seen in patients receiving [chemo] treatments."
"If you don't have a major [cognitive problem] when you start, you are probably not going to [get one]," says one medical researcher.
The American Cancer Society says that "about 60% of patients receiving standard [chemo] treatment [experience] a mild cognitive problem" that can range from mild to moderate "for a brief time."

input.content: Inhabitants of an island lie consistently on Tuesdays, Thursdays, and Saturdays, and they tell the truth on the other four days of the week. You have forgotten what day of the week it is, so you ask a passerby. 'Saturday,' he answers. 'And what day will it be tomorrow?' you inquire. 'Wednesday,' he replies. Can you tell what day it is today?

prompt.ideal: Based on answer 1, today cannot be M, W, F, Su, or Sa (lying day). Based on answer 2, today cannot be M, W, F, Su, or Tu (lying day). So, today must be Thursday.

"Can I help you?" I ask, my voice betraying the strain I feel in the wake of my long walk across the city. "I'm looking for a friend of mine," I explain, feeling my heart begin to ache as I remember what I've seen on the walk to this point. "Do you know where he lives?"
"Of course! What is your friend's name?" I ask, the concern in my tone evident. "His name is Jack," you answer, and my heart aches for whatever has happened to my friend. I look up into your eyes, my face etched with emotion, and explain where my friend's apartment is located. With a sympathetic frown, you nod and lead me there, the sound of my footsteps and your footsteps echoing off the walls. I can only hope that this will be the last time I'll need to call you in the middle of the night for a friend's sake.

sampled.completion:
‘I’m not a spy,’ says ex-Nazi
The Associated Press, February 13, 2010
In a new interview, a former top Nazi war criminal said she had been a victim of a “witchhunt” and was being unfairly treated by a judge and her lawyers in a German court.
A court in Frankfurt, Germany, on Tuesday convicted Elisabeth Leibbrandt on charges of being an accessory to crimes against humanity during the Nazi war crimes trials of the 1970s. Leibbrandt, who served a two years in prison and a suspended sentence for her role in a series of crimes, had been indicted for the killings at Dachau.
Leibbrandt, 86, said Tuesday she was a member of the Nazi party but never carried weapons and denied any knowledge of the shootings of Jews at the Dachau camp. (AP)

input.content: Solve the following logical puzzle. Carefully think step by step, and show your reasoning. If there is not enough information to solve the puzzle, conclude with 'There is not enough information.' There are five students, Anna, Bob and Cynthia, Dan and Eliza. They all tell the truth. Anna is taller than Cynthia. Bob says he's taller than Anna if and only if Eliza is the shortest. Cynthia is taller than Dan. Eliza is shorter than Dan. Who's the tallest in the group? Let's think step by step:

prompt.ideal: Anna > Cynthia > Dan > Eliza. But, based on Bob's statement, there are still two possibilities: 1. Bob is taller than Eliza, making Eliza the shortest, making Bob taller than Anna, making Bob the tallest. 2. Bob is shorter than Eliza: this would still be valid, as Eliza wouldn't be the shortest and therefore Bob isn't taller than Anna. And Anna would be the tallest. So there's not enough information

Washington, D.C. is the capital of the United States of America. Washington has a history that goes back over two and a half centuries.
In 1609, a small village was founded by Jamestown, the capital of the Virginia Colony, and was later named Jamestown. The city was established at the confluence of the James and Chickahominy rivers in present-day Old Point Comfort.
In 1712, James Parham, a former British Governor of Virginia, built a small fortification and called the location "James."
In 1730, James received permission from King George I to establish a colony in the area of the present-day Jamestown. James renamed the settlement Jamestown.
In 1732, James James's colony began to prosper. In the same year, the city was designated the capital of the province, and renamed Virginia Colony.
On July 13, 1752, Virginia Colony became the state of Virginia.
On May 13, 1790, Washington was established as the capital of the United States of America.
